documents.title: display
documents.summary: The display CSS property sets whether an element is treated as a block or inline box and the layout used for its children, such as flow layout, grid or flex.

title: <mark>display</mark>

documents.title: display
documents.summary: The display manifest member is used to specify your preferred display mode for the web application. The display mode determines how much of the browser UI is shown to the user when the app is launched within the context of an operating system. You can choose to show the full browser interface or hide it to provide a more app-like experience.

body: The <mark>display</mark> manifest member is used to specify your preferred <mark>display</mark> mode for the web application.

Note:
The value of the <mark>display</mark>-mode media feature reflects the actual <mark>display</mark> mode being used by the browser.
title: <mark>display</mark>

documents.title: display
documents.summary: The display attribute lets you control the rendering of graphical or container elements.

body: This means that any child of an element with <mark>display=</mark>"none" will never be rendered even if the child has a value for <mark>display</mark>

Note:
As a presentation attribute, <mark>display</mark> also has a CSS property counterpart: <mark>display</mark>.

to the CSS <mark>display</mark> property.
visibility attribute
CSS <mark>display</mark> property
title: <mark>display</mark>

documents.title: font-display
documents.summary: The font-display descriptor for the @font-feature-values at-rule sets the default value of how a font face is displayed based on whether and when it is downloaded. Setting a value for the font-display descriptor within a @font-feature-values block sets the default value of the font-display descriptor for the @font-face at-rule for all the fonts with the same font-family value.

body: Setting a value for the font-<mark>display</mark> descriptor within a @font-feature-values block sets the default value of the font-<mark>display</mark>
<mark>display</mark> strategy.
title: font-<mark>display</mark>

documents.title: <display-box>
documents.summary: These keywords define whether an element generates display boxes at all.

body: All descendant elements also have their <mark>display</mark> turned off.

More accessible markup with <mark>display</mark>: contents | Hidde de Vries
<mark>Display</mark>: Contents Is Not a CSS Reset | Adrian Roselli
<<mark>display</mark>-box
title: <<mark>display</mark>-box>

documents.title: <display-outside>
documents.summary: The <display-outside> keywords specify the element's outer display type, which is essentially its role in flow layout. These keywords are used as values of the display property, and can be used for legacy purposes as a single keyword, or as defined in the Level 3 specification alongside a value from the <display-inside> keywords.

body:
Note:
When browsers encounter a <mark>display</mark> property with only an outer <mark>display</mark> value (e.g., <mark>display</mark>: block or <mark>display</mark>: inline
), the inner value defaults to flow (e.g., <mark>display</mark>: block flow and <mark>display</mark>: inline flow).
title: <<mark>display</mark>-outside>

documents.title: <display-inside>
documents.summary: These keywords specify the element's inner display type, which defines the type of formatting context that lays out its contents (assuming it is a non-replaced element). These keywords are used as values of the display property, and can be used for legacy purposes as a single keyword, or as defined in the Level 3 specification alongside a value from the <display-outside> keywords.

body:
Note:
Browsers that support the two value syntax, on finding the inner value only, such as when <mark>display</mark>: flex or <mark>display</mark>:

<<mark>display</mark>-inside> =   flow       |  flow-root  |  table      |  flex       |  grid       |  ruby
Sources: CSS <mark>Display</mark> Module
title: <<mark>display</mark>-inside>

documents.title: display_override
documents.summary: The display member is used to determine the developer's preferred display mode for a website. It follows a process where the browser falls back to the next display mode if the requested one is not supported. In some advanced use cases, this fallback process might not be enough.

body: The <mark>display</mark> member is used to determine the developer's preferred <mark>display</mark> mode for a website.
consider before using the <mark>display</mark> member.
title: <mark>display</mark>_override

documents.title: <display-listitem>
documents.summary: The list-item keyword causes the element to generate a ::marker pseudo-element with the content specified by its list-style properties (for example a bullet point) together with a principal box of the specified type for its own contents.

body: <<mark>display</mark>-listitem> =   <<mark>display</mark>-outside>?     &&  [ flow | flow-root ]?

<mark>display</mark>
<<mark>display</mark>-outside>
<<mark>display</mark>-inside>
<<mark>display</mark>-internal>
<<mark>display</mark>-box>
<<mark>display</mark>-legacy>
title: <<mark>display</mark>-listitem>

documents.title: display-mode
documents.summary: The display-mode CSS media feature can be used to test whether a web app is being displayed in a normal browser tab or in some alternative way, such as a standalone app or fullscreen mode.

body:
For example:
A progressive web app can set its <mark>display</mark> mode by setting the <mark>display</mark> member in its manifest.
value of <mark>display</mark>-mode identifies the mode that was set.
The <mark>display</mark>-mode value applies to the top-level browsing context and any child browsing contexts.
title: <mark>display</mark>-mode
